content.question: An unstable nucleus of <math alttext="superscript 40 subscript 19 potassium" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mprescripts></mprescripts><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mmultiscripts></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> undergoes a <math alttext="beta raised to a negative power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> decay. What are the atomic number and nucleon number of the resulting nucleus?

choices.label: The atomic number is <math alttext="18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn></math>, and the nucleon number is <math alttext="39" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>39</mn></math>.
The atomic number is <math alttext="18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn></math>, and the nucleon number is <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math>.
The atomic number is <math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>19</mn></math>, and the nucleon number is <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math>.
The atomic number is <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math>, and the nucleon number is <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math>.

content.answer: The atomic number is <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math>, and the nucleon number is <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>40</mn></math>.
